items.abstract: <jats:p>Youth and their experiences, opinions and attitudes in post-war Bosnia and Herzegovina (hereafter BiH) have typically been left unexamined by both academics and policy makers. Nor is there much attention paid to historical analysis of youth who lived in the socialist period, which could shed some light on the mentality of young generations in present-day BiH. This article provides a historical view of socialist youth in Tito's era, with a special focus on BiH in the late 1980s. The second section provides a survey of how young people live in one of the Yugoslav successor states, BiH, examining the continuity and discontinuity of socio-political and ideological conditions in which youth lived in socialist Yugoslavia. The third section looks at the relationship between youth and the international community, the dynamics of which shed light on common features of both pre- and post-war BiH. Specifically, it will examine the internationally funded and organized “Successor Generation Initiative” (SGI) youth program, which aimed to educate youth in democratic values and develop their leadership skills.</jats:p>
title: Conversations with Bosnian Youth: From the Youth Relay Race to the Successor Generation Initiative*

reference.author: Donia
reference.volume-title: Bosnia and Herzegovina: A Tradition Betrayed

reference.author: Dedijer
reference.volume-title: Novi prilozi za biografiju Josipa Broza Tita

reference.unstructured: It is interesting to note that the mission was reluctant to promote the trip to Strasbourg during the recruitment process, fearing that the trip might be the driving motivation for youth to participate in the program. This only confirms how much youth mobility is limited and dependent on international donors.
Early Warning System Report 2006, 87.

reference.author: Topalović
reference.volume-title: Kako su komunisti dograbili vlast u Jugoslaviji

reference.unstructured: Note that 75.4% and 15% never or rarely deal with political activities, respectively. See Youth in BiH 2003.

The town of Srebrenica is located in the Serb entity of RS. Many Bosniaks and Croats do not recognize RS as a legitimate political entity, because they regard its existence as presumably being rooted in a war crime.
Note that 37.1% of youth are totally or partially uncertain and 32.2% only partially certain that their education will make it possible for them to gain employment. See Youth in BiH 2003.
Note that 95.6% and 94.1% of young people are neither a member of an NGO nor of a political party, respectively. See Youth in BiH 2003.
Fagan, “Civil Society Ten Years after Dayton,” 414.

In the Balkans, national (ethnic) and religious identities have blended and are often applied interchangeably. Since the war, religious institutions have exerted significant influence in the school system (curricula). The current school system in BiH is extremely politicized and represents the most effective instrument for ethnic segregation of children and young people (“two schools under one roof” and bussing children to mono-ethnic schools). See Bozic, “Reeducating Bosnian Hearts,” East European Politics and Societies, May 2006.
Early Warning System Report 2006, 31.

As mentioned above, there was a “nationalist”/“federalist” divide within the party. Thus, it was not only non-communist nationalists, as commonly believed, who sparked nationalist debates and tensions.
Ivan Lovrenović and Rasim Kadic, interviews.
Božić Gordana . “Reeducating Bosnian Hearts: An Essay on Education System in BiH.” East European Politics and Societies, May 2006.
Although two of the 10 cantons are ethnically “mixed,” the ethnic division is present at the municipal level, best exemplified by the education system that endorses school segregation.
United Nations in BiH, Youth in BiH 2003, 17.
Ibid., 411.
Donia and Fine, Bosnia & Herzegovina, 200.

reference.author: Ramet
reference.volume-title: Social Currents in Eastern Europe: The Sources and Meaning of the Great Transformation

reference.unstructured: Note that 36.2% of youth do not vote, out of which 16.9% state that none of the political options represent their views, 13.7% believe their vote cannot change anything, while 20.3% are simply not interested. See Youth in BiH 2003.
Ramet “Apocalypse Culture and Social Change in Yugoslavia,” 11.
OSCE Mission to BiH, Youth Programme, Draft Strategic Plan.
Rasim Kadić, interview.
Manojlo Tomić, “Odlazak Greganovića: Jos jedan poraz,” Nasi Dani, June 1989, 7.
Unlike other Yugoslav republics, BiH did not have a “titular” nation. Rather, the republic was composed of three ethnic groups, namely Serbs, Croats and Muslims.
Donia and Fine, Bosnia & Herzegovina, 197; Glenny, The Fall of Yugoslavia, 148.

For example, the Early Warning System indicates that 15% of ethnic minority members felt discriminated in Bosniak majority areas; 28% of the ethnic minority living in the Croat majority area felt the same; and 15% of minority groups living among Serbs felt that their civil or ethnic rights are violated.

It had its roots in the ideological glorification of the memory of young people's war sacrifices and their revolutionary spirit. For example, fallen youth were given the highest honor of the People's Hero, while the underlining themes of youth and war were covered excessively in schools, the socialist literature and arts, and cinematography (e.g. the “Bosko Buha” film).
Rasim Kadić, interview by author, Sarajevo, 17 August 2005; and Ivan Lovrenović, interview, Toronto, 13 May 2005.
Trefor Williams, OSCE Democratization Director, interview by author, Sarajevo, 17 August 2005.

For example, two experiences, namely the “National Liberation Struggle” and the conflict with Stalin in 1948, significantly shaped the country's ideology, socio-political developments, and Yugoslavia's value systems.
Fahrudin Djapo, “Intervju: Dr. Kasim Trnka. Bosna kao Svajcarska,” Nasi Dani, May 1990, 10.
Malcolm, Bosnia, 201–02.
Ivan Lovrenović, interview.
Rusinow, “Nationalities Policy and the ‘National Question,’” 134.
Ivan Lovrenovic and Rasim Kadic, interviews.
It is estimated that around 100 independent grassroots organizations and 10 political associations existed in Slovenia in the late 1980s. See Ramet, Social Currents in Eastern Europe, 184–86.
Dedijer, Novi prilozi za biografiju Josipa Broza Tita, 389, 511.
OSCE Mission to BiH, Successor Generation Initiative.
Early Warning System Report 2006, 41.
Job, Yugoslavia's Ruin, 22; emphasis added.
For example, 70.9% of young people often visit family and friends; 72.2% spend their time often or regularly at home. See Youth in BiH 2003.
Rasim Kadić, interview.
Ivan Lovrenovic and Rasim Kadic, interviews.
Donia and Fine, Bosnia & Herzegovina, 204.

The voluntary “working actions” furnished young people with a sense of achievement and responsibility towards the country. Equally important, it created the conditions for youth to improve their personal lives. On one hand, working actions employed the official ideology in order to mobilize youth voluntary labor for the efficient and rapid development of the country. On the other, the detrimental effects of the underdeveloped labor market on young people and the absence of adequate educational institutions were cushioned by the existence of the “working action.” The working action was a “school” where thousands of young men and women became literate while building schools for future generations. It was a “cultural community” where youth developed appreciation for sports and arts while building youth clubs, and cultural and recreational centers. In addition, although its ideological objective to bring together youth of different ethnic and religious backgrounds is generally acknowledged and emphasized, it is often forgotten that working on national projects, such as railways and highways, was the only opportunity for social mobility for young people in the immediate post-war years.
Topalović, Kako su komunisti dograbili vlast u Jugoslaviji, 82.

Zihad Kljucanin, “Stari i mladi revolucionari,” Nasi Dani, December 1989, 46. The National Liberation Struggle involved both the war against the Axis occupying powers and the war against ultranationalists and Axis collaborators, Serb Chetniks and Croat/ Muslim Ustashe. It was organized and led by a communist, Josip Broz Tito.
Rusinow, “Nationalities Policy and the ‘National Question,’” 132.
Dedijer, Novi prilozi za biografiju Josipa Broza Tita, 511; emphasis added; author's translation.
Early Warning System Report 2006, 42.

Although retail prices and overall living costs increased as a result of the introduction of VAT, the impact was not as dramatic as expected. Some payments were made to mitigate the impact of VAT on the most vulnerable groups, such as pensioners and recipients of social welfare. Early Warning System Report 2006, 32–34.

reference.author: Woodward
reference.volume-title: Socialist Unemployment: The Political Economy of Yugoslavia 1945–1990

reference.unstructured: Mirsad Halilović, “S.O.S. za SSO: Omladinska vozanja,” Nasi Dani, August 1989, 24; Ivan Lovrenović, interview.
Rasim Kadić, interview.
Allcock, Explaining Yugoslavia, 91.
Allcock, Explaining Yugoslavia, 79.
Donia and Fine, Bosnia & Herzegovina, 180–82.
Early Warning System Report 2006, 46.
Allcock, Explaining Yugoslavia, 421.
Early Warning System Report 2006, 54–55.
Mirsad Halilović and Miso Vidović, “Neka se partija ugleda na omladinsku organizaciju,” Naši Dani, December 1989, 22.

Tito was inconsistent with his birth date. Although his birth certificate shows that he was born on 7 May 1892, his birthday was celebrated officially on 25 May. See Dedijer, Novi prilozi za biografiju Josipa Broza Tita, 136–37. The Tito Relay Race was originally designed to carry birthday greetings to Tito by young people. However, in response to the criticism against the “cult of personality” voiced at the 20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Tito insisted that the official celebration of his birthday be renamed Youth Day. See Milovan Djilas, Druženje s Titom, 21–22. The Youth Relay Day consisted of sports and cultural events, youth and children's competitions, rally celebrations, and even rock concerts. Socialist Youth Organizations and the Yugoslav People's Army were the main organizers of the event.
“Union of Socialist Youth of Yugoslavia,” Yugoslav Survey (1974), 40–41.
Woodward, Socialist Unemployment, 215.

The UN defines youth as individuals between the ages of 14 and 25. Generally, the international community interprets the definition more flexibly, taking into account the long-term effects of the war on young people and thereby extending the range of ages.

With the help of UN reconstruction funds and youth voluntarism, the country's devastated infrastructure and productivity was brought to pre-war conditions and levels by the end of 1946, two years after the Second World War ended. See Donia and Fine, Bosnia & Herzegovina, 165. Compare this to the bleak prediction that in present-day BiH economic recovery may not reach pre-war levels before 2010. Although cynics would argue that it was labor prisons, and not only youth brigades, that helped the reconstruction of postwar Yugoslavia, the importance of the contribution and enthusiasm of youth in the first years after the war can hardly be exaggerated.

In the Yugoslav context, youth apathy represented a shift from supra-nationalism to ethnic nationalism. However, widespread youth apathy in other Western democracies may represent a shift from trust in political parties (regardless of their ideology) to that in interest groups. See Cross, Political Parties, 20.
Woodward, Socialist Unemployment, 77–78, 9, 121, 243.

From now on, the revolutionary or war legacy of youth (established in the 1941–1944 war) refers to youth as an abstract category and not to the experiences of “old revolutionaries,” the younger generation that directly participated in the “National Liberation Struggle.”
Allcock, Explaining Yugoslavia, 269.
Donia and Fine, Bosnia & Herzegovina, 192.
Rasim Kadić and Ivan Lovrenovic, interviews.
Rasim Kadić and Ivan Lovrenovic, interviews.
Glenny, The Fall of Yugoslavia, 148.
Rasim Kadić, interview.
Rasim Kadić, interview.
Ibid.
Malcolm, Bosnia, 197–98; see also Donia and Fine, Bosnia & Herzegovina, 175–78.
Allcock, Explaining Yugoslavia, 90.
Woodward, Socialist Unemployment, 234.
Mustafa Topčagić “‘Student” na lomamači,” Naši Dani, May 1989.
There were student demonstration in Sarajevo, BiH, too, but their demands were moderate.
Ramet, “The Yugoslav Press in Flux,” 102–03.
UNDP, Early Warning System Report 2006 (Web edition), 41–42.
Pugh, “Transformation in the Political Economy of Bosnia since Dayton,” 455, 457.

items.abstract: <jats:p>The crystal structures of four cocrystals of pyrazine with benzene polycarboxylic acids were determined, namely pyrazine–phthalic (benzene-1,2-dicarboxylic) acid (1/1), C<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>·C<jats:sub>8</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>), pyrazine–hemimellitic (benzene-1,2,3-tricarboxylic) acid (1/1), C<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>·C<jats:sub>9</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>6</jats:sub> (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>), pyrazine–hemimellitic acid–water (1/2/2), C<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>·2C<jats:sub>9</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>·2H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O (<jats:bold>2a</jats:bold>), and pyrazine–pyromellitic (benzene-1,2,4,5-tetracarboxylic) acid (3/1), 3C<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>·C<jats:sub>10</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>8</jats:sub> (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>). In all cases, infinite chains of alternating acid and base molecules, bonded by O—H...N hydrogen bonds, are formed. However, the details of the supramolecular structures are different. The additional carboxylic acid groups in the tri- and tetracarboxylic acids participate in hydrogen bonding with neighbouring acid molecules (in <jats:bold>2</jats:bold>), water molecules, which makes the structure more complicated (in <jats:bold>2a</jats:bold>), or with additional pyrazine molecules (in <jats:bold>3</jats:bold>). π–π interactions between aromatic rings help organize the crystal architectures in all cases except for hydrate <jats:bold>2a</jats:bold>. In that case, the hydrogen-bond-enriched structure enforces a disposition of the rings in which no stacking is observed. The Hirshfeld surface analysis allows better visualization of the differences between the structures by fingerprint plots in particular.</jats:p>
title: Cocrystals of pyrazine and benzene polycarboxylic acids
